Award.AwardTitle: A Full-scale Development Proposal -Informal Community Science Investigators (iCSI): Next Generation Engagement for Informal Science Institutions

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Education and Human Resources

Award.AbstractNarration:
Informal Community Science Investigators (iCSI) creates a network of four geographically diverse informal science institutions working together on strategies to engage youth ages 10-13 through location based augmented reality (AR) games played on smartphones. These high-interest, kid-friendly games will be used by families visiting the institutions and by youth who enroll in more intensive summer camp programs. Using AR games, participants will engage in playful but scientifically-grounded investigations drawing on each institution's research, exhibits, and natural spaces. For example, a botanical garden might engage young visitors through AR games with themes related to native and invasive species, while a zoo might create a game experience focusing on illegal wildlife trade. Participants in the iCSI summer camp program will have more intensive experiences, including work with the host institution's scientists, opportunities to develop original augmented reality games, and experiences with game-related service learning and citizen science programs. For both target groups (families and campers), the location specific games build understanding of both the institution's mission and the broader realm of scientific research and application.

The project will test the notion of participants as "learner hero," the link between game play and the individual's development of competency, autonomy and the relationship to real world experience, in this case through community action on the subject of the game developed. To that end, participants will be encouraged to extend their involvement through related investigations on site and participation in community activities and projects that can be done at home. Social media tools such as Facebook and web sites managed by the host institutions will provide recognition for this extended engagement, helping participants maintain ties to the program. Additionally, program resources provide assistance to adult family members in nurturing and sustaining youth interest in STEM activities and careers.

A major effort of the project will be development of a new software infrastructure called TaleBlazer for the augmented reality game that will enable teachers and students to develop their own game that incorporates real data collection and scientific model building. The new platform will enhance the game play platform MITAR developed with NSF funding.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The Informal Community Science Investigators (iCSI) project extended a partnership between the Missouri Botanical Garden (MBG) and the Massachusetts Institute of Technology (MIT) focused on engaging youth in community-based projects highlighting the STEM (science, technology, engineering, and math) disciplines. Other efforts within this MBG-MIT partnership have included applications of commercial geospatial technology and youth-developed environmental simulation projects using MIT’s StarLogo tools. For the iCSI project, the focus was on use of handheld augmented reality quests to engage youth ages 10-13 in a variety of environmentally-themed investigations based at informal science institutions. These quests are created by educators at each institution using MIT’s TaleBlazer software, a web-based authoring tool. Quests are subsequently downloaded to a  smartphone or tablet and played through an iOS or Android app. Participants take on a quest which guides them as they navigate the grounds guided by GPS signals, make close observations, and integrate what they see in the world with supporting data provided in the app. Examples of projects developed under iCSI funding include one at the Missouri Botanical Garden where youth participants take on the role of Hibiscus Mallow, a visitor from a parallel universe. With the transporter broken down, Hibiscus needs to find the plants required (in the right amounts) to meet nutritional needs and survive until a rescue ship can arrive. In this process, youth participants investigate a range of plants on the grounds at the Garden, assess them for their nutritional value, and make decisions based on data provided within the simulation. At Red Butte Garden (an iCSI partner site), youth participants took up the Garden’s interest in controlling invasive species by going on a quest to defeat the fictional Lady Nightshade. 

Primary program operations took place at the Missouri Botanical Garden and at 3 partner sites: The Columbus Zoo and Aquarium in Ohio, the San Diego Zoo in California, and the Red Butte Botanical Garden in Utah. At each location, week-long summer programs linked youth with the local institution’s science and conservation staff in support of field work on the grounds and in the community, leading toward the creation of original youth-designed TaleBlazer quests. Through these efforts, participants were introduced to a variety of STEM-related careers and came to see the relevance of a variety of technical and interpersonal skills. Focus group and survey responses from participants, as well as focus group responses from parents, showed that youth interest in STEM fields was enhanced, and in many cases broadened beyond initial expectations. For example participants who signed up expecting a technology-focused experience came to appreciate broader science concerns, whereas some who were initially attracted to the program based on an environmental interest had their awareness and interest in technology broadened.  In addition to these camp programs, education staff at the partner institutions developed and tested a variety of TaleBlazer games for public use. These experiences helped to develop a greater understanding of the challenges and opportunities institutions face in leveraging handheld technology to engage visitors, and are useful in informing ongoing development efforts. 

To enable these projects to take place, MIT developed and refined the TaleBlazer platform. Using these web-based tools, youth as young as 10 years old, as well as staff at partner sites with no specialized technology skills, were able to create, share, and revise site-specific quests. Before iCSI, a pilot version of the software offered limited functions which created a number of obstacles for participants. The iCSI grant funded considerable expansion in the software’s capacity as well as improvements in its user interface. Also, to support local engagement, MIT is now able to partner with organizations such as a zoo or botanical garden to make their games easily accessible by visitors. Players can see the closest “TaleBlazer Place” on the app’s home screen, or they can also search for featured games in the area using a list or map interface. To support iterative improvements in the design of local quests, MIT also implemented an analytics platform to allow designers at each site to collect and view anonymous data about their games.

Looking ahead, it is clear that handheld devices will continue to be a significant part of people’s experiences at informal institutions. Through iCSI, the partners developed, tested, and refined a highly functional software platform to enable these experiences, as well as project design materials to support local project development by informal science center staff. These materials and the TaleBlazer software were shared with other institutions through an 8-week webinar series designed to support participants’ own projects, and are now available at no cost for public use. The iCSI project staff are actively consulting with others looking to take these efforts further.
